news_summary: A meaningful gift has inspired and significantly influenced a successful career in science.

articles.title: The gift that shaped my career in science
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03897-6Nature asked about your most memorable scientific gifts. You delivered.
articles.content:
“The most beautiful gift was given to me by my father in the 1970s when, for a small amount of money, he rented a house with other families in a small, abandoned mining village located deep in the woods of the Metalliferous Hills in Tuscany, Italy. I was less than ten years old and, with the other children, I was able to run freely among tunnels, mineshafts and mineral dumps. I remember that we used to talk with passionate mineral prospectors who had pushed deep into the antimony mine, right up to the actual mineral veins. It is probable that my passion for minerals and rocks was born right then. Today, I am a geologist and I have been teaching science for 30 years.”

Gianni Bianciardi, geologist, Siena, Italy.

“My best science gift is undoubtedly my ex-husband. He encouraged me to start studying — because, as he said, he was successful in his academic studies and I was much smarter than him. He further enabled me by gradually taking over many of the household tasks. I started my studies when I was 33, took three years at community college to get a two-year degree (while I still had small children at home), three years to finish the bachelor’s, both with a perfect 4.0 average, then four years to do both my master’s and PhD. I received my PhD when I was 43, with computer scientist Herb Simon at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Without my ex-husband’s encouragement and help, this would never have happened.”

Anonymous.

“I remember my grandfather offering me an hour-long guided tour of an agricultural biochemical lab while I was eight or nine years old. He explained what they did there, showed me living objects through a microscope, chemical reactions in a glass tube, models of agricultural machines and so on. In the end, I worked for decades at the particle-physics lab CERN near Geneva, Switzerland.”

Hans F. Hoffmann, retired physicist, Geneva, Switzerland.

The volcanic island Rangitoto lies in the Hauraki Gulf off the coast of New Zealand. The volcanic island Rangitoto lies in the Hauraki Gulf off the coast of New Zealand.

“I was given a tour of Rangitoto, an island in Auckland Harbour in New Zealand that is only 700 years old. Strangely, epiphytic plants that usually grow on other plants instead colonize the scoria: the aerated volcanic rocks that cover the surface of the island. Many of the plants there are otherwise rare and obscure, but have ethereal beauty, such as the kidney fern [Hymenophyllum nephrophyllum]. I fell in love once more with the flora of New Zealand. Hopefully many more people will receive this gift!”

Michele Moore, plant and environmental scientist, Christchurch, New Zealand.

“The encouragement I received from Harold Good at Queen’s University, Kingston, Canada. He inspired me to become a plant pathologist. We were kindred spirits, being equally enthralled with both the academic and practical aspects of botany. He was my scientific father, guiding and prodding in the right direction. He saw the world as it was, and provided excellent advice. The gift gave me a university position and the experience to write textbooks. What a treasure he gave me.”

Ronald Jackson, retired botanist, Oakville, Canada.
articles.reasoning: The article shares inspiring personal stories about formative gifts and encouragement that shaped successful scientific careers, highlighting the positive impact of mentorship, family support, and early exposure to science. These narratives provide hope and emotional uplift by showing how meaningful support can lead to significant educational and professional achievements with broad societal value.
articles.personality_title: How special gifts inspired scientists to follow their passion
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many scientists remember important moments or gifts that helped them discover their love for science and guided their careers.

**What happened** – Scientists from different countries shared stories about meaningful gifts or support they received. For example, a geologist from Italy recalls exploring old mines as a child, which sparked his interest in minerals. A computer scientist in the US was encouraged by her ex-husband to study, leading her to earn a PhD while raising children. A retired physicist fondly remembers a childhood tour of a science lab with his grandfather. Another scientist in New Zealand was inspired by a visit to a volcanic island to appreciate rare plants. And a Canadian botanist credits a mentor’s guidance for his career success.

**Impact** – These stories show how small acts of encouragement, family support, and early experiences can deeply influence a person’s future. They highlight the importance of mentors and opportunities that help people explore science, even in unexpected ways. This helps us understand how personal connections and experiences can shape scientists who contribute to knowledge and society.

**What's next step** – Sharing these stories may encourage more families, teachers, and mentors to support young people’s curiosity. It might also inspire others to reflect on the positive influences in their own lives and pass on encouragement to future generations.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Personal gifts and encouragement often play a key role in helping people discover and succeed in science careers.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment des cadeaux spéciaux ont inspiré des scientifiques à suivre leur passion
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – De nombreux scientifiques se souviennent de moments ou de cadeaux importants qui les ont aidés à découvrir leur amour pour la science et à orienter leur carrière.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des scientifiques de différents pays ont partagé des histoires sur des cadeaux ou un soutien significatif qu’ils ont reçus. Par exemple, un géologue italien se rappelle avoir exploré des mines abandonnées enfant, ce qui a éveillé son intérêt pour les minéraux. Une informaticienne aux États-Unis a été encouragée par son ex-mari à étudier, ce qui l’a menée à obtenir un doctorat tout en élevant ses enfants. Un physicien retraité se souvient avec affection d’une visite d’un laboratoire scientifique avec son grand-père. Une autre scientifique en Nouvelle-Zélande a été inspirée par une visite d’une île volcanique à apprécier des plantes rares. Et un botaniste canadien attribue sa réussite à l’aide d’un mentor.

**Impact** – Ces histoires montrent comment de petits gestes d’encouragement, le soutien familial et les premières expériences peuvent profondément influencer l’avenir d’une personne. Elles soulignent l’importance des mentors et des opportunités qui aident à explorer la science, même de manière inattendue. Cela aide à comprendre comment les liens personnels et les expériences façonnent les scientifiques qui contribuent au savoir et à la société.

**Prochaine étape** – Partager ces récits pourrait encourager plus de familles, enseignants et mentors à soutenir la curiosité des jeunes. Cela pourrait aussi inspirer d’autres à réfléchir aux influences positives dans leur vie et à transmettre cet encouragement aux futures générations.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des cadeaux et encouragements personnels jouent souvent un rôle clé pour aider les gens à découvrir et réussir dans les carrières scientifiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo regalos especiales inspiraron a científicos a seguir su pasión
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchos científicos recuerdan momentos o regalos importantes que les ayudaron a descubrir su amor por la ciencia y a guiar sus carreras.

**Qué pasó** – Científicos de varios países compartieron historias sobre regalos significativos o apoyo que recibieron. Por ejemplo, un geólogo de Italia recuerda explorar minas abandonadas de niño, lo que despertó su interés por los minerales. Una científica informática en EE.UU. fue animada por su exesposo a estudiar, logrando un doctorado mientras criaba a sus hijos. Un físico jubilado recuerda con cariño una visita a un laboratorio con su abuelo. Otra científica en Nueva Zelanda se inspiró en una visita a una isla volcánica para apreciar plantas raras. Y un botánico canadiense atribuye su éxito a la guía de un mentor.

**Impacto** – Estas historias muestran cómo pequeños actos de apoyo, la ayuda familiar y las primeras experiencias pueden influir mucho en el futuro de una persona. Destacan la importancia de los mentores y las oportunidades para explorar la ciencia, incluso de formas inesperadas. Esto nos ayuda a entender cómo las conexiones personales y experiencias forman a científicos que contribuyen al conocimiento y a la sociedad.

**Próximo paso** – Compartir estas historias puede animar a más familias, maestros y mentores a apoyar la curiosidad de los jóvenes. También puede inspirar a otros a pensar en las influencias positivas en sus vidas y a transmitir ese apoyo a futuras generaciones.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los regalos y el apoyo personal suelen ser clave para ayudar a las personas a descubrir y triunfar en carreras científicas.
